scenario:
Prologis, the largest owner of industrial real estate in the US and the largest REIT of any kind, has seen its stock fall by over 20% from its 52-week high due to concerns over industrial real estate and interest rate environment. Despite this, the company's business is performing well, with a massive portfolio of 1.2 billion square feet of rentable space on four continents, leased to 6,700 customers including Amazon, Home Depot, FedEx, and UPS. 

The company's occupancy has fallen from 97.7% to 95.9% over the past two years, and its retention rate is 70 basis points lower, but this is seen as a normalization after an excellent few years. The high-interest rate environment has also put pressure on commercial real estate values, with industrial property values down by about 25% since 2021.

However, there are reasons to be optimistic about Prologis. E-commerce demand continues to rise, with only 22.5% of retail sales being e-commerce in Prologis' markets, expected to reach nearly 30% by 2028. The company has also been quietly getting into the data center real estate business, targeting $7-8 billion in development spending by 2028. 

Prologis has a great track record of creating shareholder value through development, estimated at $13.6 billion so far, and sees the potential for over $40 billion in future development. The company also has lots of embedded rent growth in its portfolio, with market rates about 35% more than it is currently receiving from its properties, on average.

Prologis trades for a significant discount to its historical price-to-FFO valuation, making it an attractive time for patient long-term investors to buy. The company's strong fundamentals, combined with the expected lower interest rate environment, make it a solid business with potential for growth.
